sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The official Preliminary Estimate of GDP suggests that the UK economy contracted in the first quarter of this year by 0.2 per cent. This follows a fall of 0.3 per cent in the final quarter of last year (figure 1). This return to ‘technical’ recession has unsurprisingly generated significant coverage in the media about a ‘double dip’. It is possible that this technical recession will disappear in subsequent vintages of data as the Office for National Statistics (ONS) incorporates more information. But it is unlikely that future revisions will change the broader picture of an economy in a very weak state. NIESR's monthly estimate of GDP suggests that 50 months, or more than four years, after the start of the recession GDP is still 4.4 per cent below its pre-recession peak.

caption.p: Real GDP growth (per cent per quarter)

sec.p: Looking through the quarterly movements in data, the latest figures from the ONS show an economy that can best be described as ‘flat’. A centred three-month rolling average of our monthly estimate of GDP suggests the level of economic activity in March 2012 was the same as that in September 2010. Such weakness is likely to persist over the next two quarters. Overall, we do not expect the economy to expand this year. Looking ahead, we forecast 2 per cent growth next year followed by 2.7 per cent per annum in 2014 and 2015, before moderating to around 2 1/2 per cent per annum over the medium term. Thus, from 2014 onwards, we project a sustained period of GDP growth above the UK's potential growth rate, gradually closing the negative output gap.

The CBI's Industrial Trends Survey for the second quarter of this year suggests improvement in manufacturing sector sentiment over future demand. In recent months broad measures of lending conditions have eased (see figure A2 in the World Chapter of this Review). It is possible that some of this easing is a spillover from the longer-term refinancing operations of the ECB. Nevertheless, this figure also shows that lending conditions remain restrictive in comparison to 2010 and 2011. Although we have revised up our forecast for business investment, we still expect the volume of investment to contract by 1.3 per cent this year.

Domestic funding conditions remain constrained. The Bank of England's April 2012 Trends in Lending publication highlights that the stock of loans to small and medium sized enterprises (SMEs) continues to contract. The Bank of England's Credit Conditions Survey for the first quarter of this year suggests that some of this is related to reduced demand from SMEs. The respective contributions of supply and demand factors are not clear. The introduction of the Government's National Loan Guarantee Scheme (NLGS) should ease the price of credit to some SMEs but, as we note below, is unlikely to increase the stock of available credit by much. The UK banking system remains a significant domestic risk to the recovery. We assume that lending conditions continue to ease over the course of this year. However, if banks scale back their balance sheets more aggressively, or we see wholesale market conditions deteriorate due to further adverse economic shocks, we would expect to see economic growth weaker than currently projected.

sec.p: The Euro Area poses both the major upside and downside risks to the UK economy. Certainly the aggregate spread of corporate bonds over sovereign bonds in the Euro Area has narrowed by more than we assumed in the forecast published in our January Review. Further improvements in funding conditions for banks and sovereigns pose an upside risk to our Euro Area forecast, especially if this actually leads to an easing of credit conditions for firms and households. Such developments could have significant positive spillovers for the UK economy. Downside risks from the Euro Area remain. Such scenarios have been discussed in Holland and Kirby (2011) and Euroframe (2012) and would cause UK GDP for the year as a whole to fall.

In our January Review we highlighted the effect of temporary $20 and $30 oil price spikes on the UK economy, due to heightened tensions with Iran. Oil prices have deviated from our baseline projection by around $13 in the second quarter of this year. Information from oil futures curves suggests this increase is a temporary oil price spike. We use our global econometric model, NiGEM, to determine the likely effect on the UK economy. We assume monetary policy authorities in oil-consuming nations do not respond by tightening policy. The negative impact on GDP growth in the UK will be around 0.1 percentage point this year. Our estimates suggest that the rate of inflation would be 0.2 percentage point higher this year and next as a consequence.

We have revised up our forecast for CPI inflation for this year by 0.4 percentage point to 2.6 per cent. This upward revision is split between the effect of the oil price increases and a stronger outturn than expected for inflation in the first quarter of this year. We expect inflation to drop below the MPC's inflation target by the end of this year (figure 2). The modal forecast is conditional on no further shocks hitting the UK economy. Figure 2 reports confidence intervals around our forecast for CPI inflation, derived from stochastic simulations. As figure 2 shows there is considerable uncertainty around the future path of CPI inflation. More persistent rates of inflation would be consistent with greater price stickiness than we have assumed, a smaller output gap than our estimates imply, or higher import prices.

caption.p: CPI fan chart (per cent per annum)

sec.p: The MPC has recently highlighted concerns over stronger rates of inflation than expected in their February forecast. Both average earnings growth (figure A2) and household inflation expectations (figure A1) have moderated in recent months, suggesting there is little inflationary pressure from the domestic economy at present. However, the MPC has expressed some concern that the CPI inflation rate has not eased by as much as expected. The credibility of monetary policy is never guaranteed. But, given that we expect inflation to drop below target at the end of this year, the MPC should not let the current inflation rates constrain them from any further actions necessary to stimulate a weak economy. Over the past year inflation rates have more to do with temporary factors that drop out of the index this year.

Figure 3 reports the evolution of financial markets' expectations of the future path of short-term interest rates. Expectations have been stable between January and April of this year. Current expectations are for the cycle of rate tightening to begin in the second quarter of 2014, around the time we expect GDP to return to its pre-recession peak. It takes time for conventional changes in monetary policy to feed through into the real economy (around two years in normal times). But even with the benefit of unconventional policies such as quantitative easing (QE), the precarious state of the banking system limits the effectiveness of policy. Further stimulus would support the weak economy, but it remains our preference for fiscal policy responses rather than further increases in the size of the Bank of England's balance sheet.

caption.p: Interest rate expectations

sec.p: The government continues without deviation from its plan for fiscal consolidation. In the recent Budget there were a number of changes to the distribution of the tax and benefit system, but overall the Budget was fiscally neutral. The net fiscal multiplier is likely to be close to zero. It remains our view that fiscal policy could be used to raise aggregate demand in the economy with little to no loss of fiscal credibility. We have never and do not now advocate scaling back the government's medium-to longer-term policy of fiscal consolidation.1 However, the UK suffers from a lack of demand in the short term. As we noted in our January Review, a 1 per cent of GDP increase in government investment this year would boost GDP by around 0.7 per cent, assuming no reaction by the MPC. As we note below, net investment is being pared back significantly under the government's fiscal consolidation plan. A temporary boost to net investment would have no direct effect on the government's primary fiscal target of balancing the cyclically-adjusted current budget in 2016–17. Indeed, a temporary stimulus of any kind by definition would have no effect on the government's primary fiscal target.

The Office for Budget Responsibility's (OBR) evaluation of the government's fiscal policy suggests a better than even chance of a cyclically adjusted current budget in balance by 2016–17. The 6 per cent of GDP tightening in the structural current budget over the period 2010–11 to 2016–17 is enough to ensure this. Our estimates lead us to a similar conclusion on the basis of our current forecast. We expect the current budget to have a deficit of around 1 1/2 per cent of GDP in 2016–17, but this is on a cyclically unadjusted basis. Accounting for the output gap, our estimates suggest the structural budget will be in surplus by around 1/2 per cent of GDP. The government is not just concerned with balancing the current budget. Reductions in net investment add a further 2.2 per cent of GDP to its consolidation plan by 2016–17 (the overall consolidation is equivalent to 8.2 per cent of GDP). Reducing overall borrowing is the first step towards beginning to reverse the increase in government debt.

The government's secondary fiscal target is for public sector net debt as a per cent of GDP to be lower in 2015–16 than in 2014–15. We continue to expect the government to miss this target, but by a modest amount. This should not be of much concern; government debt, as a per cent of GDP, stabilises around this time. We expect gross government debt to stabilise at a peak of around 96 per cent of GDP. The debt to GDP ratio gradually eases due to the dynamics of robust growth and a balanced structural budget. In the absence of additional fiscal tightening in future Parliamentary terms it will take 10–15 years just to return gross debt to 60 per cent of GDP.

The UK's effective exchange rate has risen further since the publication of our January Review. The effective exchange rate appreciated by 1.3 per cent in the first quarter of this year and 1.1 per cent in the first three weeks of April. We assume that bilateral exchange rates remain stable for the first three quarters of our forecast before moving in line with the path implied by uncovered interest rate parity. This implies a modest appreciation over the next few years.

sec.title: Prices and earnings
sec.p: In the first quarter of this year the rate of CPI inflation was still more than 1 percentage point above target. But, although the inflation rate picked up from 3.4 per cent per annum in February 2012 to 3.5 per cent in March 2012, the rate of inflation is on a clear downward trajectory. The rate of CPI inflation in the first quarter of this year fell below the average rate in 2011 and is down more than 1.7 percentage points from the peak of 5.2 per cent per annum in September 2011. A similar pattern is evident for the other measures of consumer price inflation (RPI and RPIX).

The scale of consumer price inflation overstates the underlying inflationary pressure in the economy. Figure 4 reports the annual rate of growth in three National Accounts deflators: for GDP at market prices, GDP at basic prices and consumer spending (the consumption expenditure deflator, CED). The CED inflation rate is usually similar to the CPI inflation rate and was above 4 per cent per annum throughout 2011.

caption.p: National accounts price deflators (per cent per annum)

sec.p: The two GDP deflators are wider measures of price inflation and suggest significantly less inflationary pressure then the CED measure.2 The basic price deflator excludes the effect of indirect tax changes and as such allows us to view the rate of inflation without the distortions of discretionary indirect tax changes.3 The basic price deflator peaked at 4.5 per cent per annum in the final quarter of 2008 and dropped below 2 per cent per annum at the end of 2009. In the final quarter of last yearhe basic price deflator reached 1.5 per cent per annum, suggesting little underlying inflationary pressure in the UK economy.

We expect measures of consumer price inflation to converge on the GDP deflators over the next couple of years. CPI inflation is expected to remain below but close to target through to the end of 2016. Underlying our forecasts is a significant output gap over the whole of this period. Figure 2 suggests there is a significant risk of the rate of inflation being close to zero per cent.

Nominal wage growth has failed to keep pace with the rate of inflation since 2008. In the first quarter of this year nominal wage growth has decelerated even further. The moderation occurs in the growth rates of both the total pay and regular pay components of Average Weekly Earnings. It is most pronounced in the public sector, excluding financial services, where annual pay growth slowed to 0.6 per cent in the three months to February 2012 from 2.4 per cent in the three months to March 2011 (figure A2). With the government extending the public sector pay restraint to 2014–15, regular pay growth in the public sector will remain muted. We do not expect private sector wage growth to pick up much over the next few years, but with the sharp reduction in the rate of inflation we do expect private sector employees to see their pay begin to rise in real terms towards the end of this year.

sec.title: Components of expenditure
sec.p: Domestic demand declined by 0.8 per cent in 2011, dragging down GDP growth by a similar amount. This was offset by a 1 percentage point contribution from net trade. These contributions clearly do not sum to the aggregate GDP growth rate of 0.7 per cent in 2011. In the current vintage of the Quarterly National Accounts, 0.5 percentage point of GDP growth is allocated to a residual category. This occurs as the ONS marries the information it has from the different approaches to the calculation of GDP. In future Blue Book releases the residual will be allocated to the different components of expenditure, which will help to clarify the actual position of domestic and external demand.

Our forecast for GDP growth is little revised from that published in our January Review. However, there have been larger revisions to the components of expenditure. Figure 5 plots these revisions for the years 2011 to 2013. The major upward revisions to this year are the contributions from private sector investment and consumer spending. As noted in the introduction, the expected contraction in business investment has been revised down (revising up the contribution to GDP growth), due to the improvements in business perceptions of the outlook for demand. The contribution from consumer spending in 2012 has been revised up by almost 1/2 percentage point. This is primarily due to a stronger than expected outturn at the end of last year and more robust growth at the start of this year, as suggested by retail sales data.4 We have revised little of the remainder of the pattern of consumer spending this year, although we have assumed the upward shift in the level of consumer spending at the start of this year is not reversed in subsequent quarters.

caption.p: Revisions to contributions to GDP growth

sec.p: The contribution of net trade has been revised down by 1 percentage point this year. A stronger domestic economy than previously projected leads to less of a fall in imports than in our January forecast, but we also expect a sharper fall in export volumes this year (a 1.6 per cent fall instead of 0.6 per cent). At least half of this revision is related to the trade data for the first two months of the year. Figure 6 shows the contributions to quarterly GDP growth from net trade in our January 2012 and current forecast. We have revised the contribution in the first quarter from a positive 0.4 percentage point to −0.3 percentage point. This is related mainly to the Euro Area. In the three months to February 2012 the volume of goods exported to the Euro Area was still 7.7 per cent below the pre-recession level. This compares to non-EU exports, which were 20.7 per cent above their pre-recession level (figure A3). Furthermore, the volume of goods exports to the EU declined by 1.2 per cent per quarter in the three months to February 2012. Growth of 2.4 per cent growth in non-EU goods was not enough to offset this decline due to the relative weighting of exports to the EU.

caption.p: The contribution of net trade to quarterly GDP growth

sec.p: Demand from the Euro Area could still prove elusive in the near term. Much of the Euro Area is in recession. There is a risk that export volumes will contract even more sharply than we currently expect. But, as figures 5 and 6 show, we expect a broadly similar contribution from net trade next year as demand from the Euro Area accelerates. We expect export volume growth to reach 5 1/4 per cent in 2013 rising to 7 1/2 per cent in 2014. Import volume growth is expected to be a more modest 3–4 1/2 per cent per annum. Robust growth in the UK is expected to depend on the contribution from net trade. As well as its crucial role in rebalancing the UK economy, it is also an important component of the significant above-trend growth needed to close the output gap.

sec.title: Household sector
sec.p: The volume of consumer spending declined in each quarter from the final quarter of 2010 to the third quarter of 2011 before expanding in the final quarter of 2011. However, for the year as a whole consumer spending declined by 1.2 per cent, almost reversing the consumption gains made in 2010. It is likely that consumer spending increased in the first quarter of this year as well. The volume of retail sales increased by 0.8 per cent in the first quarter of this year, although this is a deceleration from the 1.1 per cent growth rate experienced at the end of 2011. Growth in the volume of retail sales would have been weaker but for the sharp increase in fuel demand caused by panic buying as consumers bought petrol in response to the risk of a strike by petrol tanker drivers.

Consumer spending estimates at the turn of the year appear to be more robust than we expected in our January forecast. It is primarily due to this that we have revised up our forecast for consumer spending growth to 1 per cent per annum, from 0.2 per cent in our January forecast. Consumer spending growth is expected to accelerate over the next few years, rising from 1 per cent per annum this year to around 2 1/2 per cent per annum in 2016. Nevertheless, the level of per capita consumer spending does not recover its pre-recession peak until 2017.

Real disposable income shrank in both 2010 and 2011, by 0.2 and 1.2 per cent per annum, respectively. Falls in real consumer wages and a relatively weak labour market contributed to this drop in real incomes. But it was the tax increases and high rate of inflation over the past two years that were the significant contributors to the fall in real incomes. With the rate of inflation dropping below target for a period, we expect UK workers, on average, to enjoy a return to real wage increases. But with such weak productivity gains forecast for the next five years there is little scope for robust real wage growth. It is this real wage growth, in combination with employment growth, which drives real income growth over the next five years.

The household saving ratio for the first three quarters of 2011 has been revised up by an average of 1.2 percentage points. The saving ratio was 7.4 per cent in 2011. We expect the household saving ratio to remain above 7 per cent through to the end of the forecast horizon. This is a necessary condition if households are to address the weakness of their balance sheets. The debt to income ratio of the household sector has been on a downward path since the onset of the financial crisis and the gradual correction of the housing market. In 2011 the net worth, in real terms, of households was still £706 billion below the peak at the end of 2007. We expect real house prices to fall by an average of 1 1/2 per cent per annum over the next five years. We thus do not expect the value of the housing stock owned by households to recover its 2007 peak, in real terms, by the end of 2016 (figure 7). The increase in the average saving behaviour of households is an increase in the net acquisition of financial assets. We expect net financial assets to increase, in real terms, by £493 billion between the end of 2011 and the end of 2016. However, even by the end of 2016, net financial assets are not expected to have recovered their peak level of 1999 (at the height of the dotcom bubble across global stock markets).

caption.p: Household real net worth

sec.title: Supply conditions
sec.p: In nominal terms business investment's share of GDP has been declining since the late 1990s (see figure 8). This, can be explained to a large degree by declining prices of investment goods (especially ICT) relative to other goods (see for discussion Bakhshi and Thompson, 2002). In real terms, the share of business investment in GDP was much more stable and had two distinct peaks: the first at the turn of the century (dotcom bubble) and the second around the time of the recent financial crisis.

From its latest peak in the fourth quarter of 2007 to its trough in the first quarter of 2011 business investment declined from 9.8 per cent to 7.7 per cent of GDP (or by 25 per cent in constant 2008 prices). Over the past year business investment growth has been erratic.

caption.p: Business investment as a share of GDP

sec.p: Private non-financial corporations had accumulated unprecedented levels of cash reserves5 before the financial crisis (see figure 9). Recently accumulation has stopped but companies seem to prefer to hold the cash. This could be as a guarantee against potential future liquidity shocks, but is more likely due to uncertainty about future demand and the absence of alternative investment options. In addition, the reduction in the level of corporate indebtedness (see figure 9) since the beginning of 2009 seems to suggest that recent corporate surpluses have been used to pay off debts.

caption.p: Cash reserves and loans of private non-financial corporations

sec.p: Many experts expect that historically high cash reserves combined with resilient corporate profitability will eventually result in impressive growth in business investment. For example, in its most recent Economic and Fiscal Outlook the OBR forecasts slow growth in business investment in 2012, impressive growth of 6–9 per cent in 2013 and 2014, and double digit growth in 2015 and 2016. The OBR forecast implies that business investment will increase to new records, as a share of GDP. The OBR justifies such high growth rates of business investment by the pattern of recovery observed after the recession in the 1990s. But in the 1990s this growth was from a much lower base.

We are much less optimistic about business investment growth over the next few years. We may have revised up our forecast for business investment this year, but it is still a contraction for the year as a whole. Despite improvements in business sentiment, uncertainty about demand is assumed to persist and is expected to weigh on business investment decisions.6

Funding conditions for banks appear to have improved somewhat, but they have certainly not returned to ‘normal’. For example, the five-year CDS prices of the major UK banks have eased, but remains above the level prior to the onset of the banking crisis. But wholesale funding remains problematic. According to the Bank of England's Credit Conditions Survey, in recent months tightening in wholesale funding conditions has resulted in a modest decrease in the availability of corporate credit for firms of all sizes.

In its Autumn Statement, the government announced a number of measures aimed at reducing the cost of borrowing for SMEs. Within the NLGS, which went live on 20 March, the government will guarantee up to £20 billion of borrowing by banks, thus enabling them to borrow at a cheaper rate. Banks then have to pass lower borrowing costs to businesses with turnovers below £50 million. We have not adjusted our forecast in light of this scheme, partially due to uncertainty about the effectiveness of the scheme and partially because the size of the first tranche (£5 billion) is not large enough to affect the aggregate level of business investment. The scheme should not be dismissed outright; it should mean that £5 billion of lending to SMEs will be distributed at a lower price than otherwise would have been the case, improving the position of their balance sheets.

The current level of business investment is not very low by historical standards (see figure 8). It is marginally above those observed at the beginning of 1997 and during 2003–5. Barrell and Riley (2006) tested the hypothesis that the level of business investment observed in 2003–5 was particularly low. Their econometric analysis did not reveal significant evidence of underinvestment, relative to the UK's historical record of business investment patterns.

The unemployment rate has decreased slightly by 0.1 percentage point during the three months to February 2012 compared to 8.3 per cent in the three months to November 2011. This was the first decrease since March-May 2011. Monthly data, however, suggests the unemployment rate has increased in the last months of the three-month period for which headline numbers are calculated (see figure 10). Unfortunately, we think it too early to call a turning point for the unemployment rate. Indeed, the claimant count continued to rise in the first quarter of this year. In March 2012 it reached 1.61 million, up 3,600 on the previous month and up 145,200 on the same month a year earlier.

caption.p: Unemployment rate, monthly data

sec.p: The employment rate (70.4 per cent) and the number of people in employment (29.17 million) have increased slightly by 0.1 percentage point and 53,000 correspondingly during the three months to February. However, this was due to an increase of 80,000 in the number of part-time workers, while the number of full-time workers fell by 27,000.

This rise in part-time employment has also seen an increase in the share of workers that report that they are working part-time because they cannot find full time employment (see figure 11). In the UK 18 per cent of part-time workers (or 4.8 per cent of total employment) are working part-time, not out of choice in the three months to February 2012. The number of people that fall under this definition has increased by 356,000 to 1.4 million in just two years (an increase of 34 per cent).

caption.p: Proportion working part-time because could not find full-time employment

sec.p: Some types of unemployment leave more persistent marks on the labour force and can contribute to a higher equilibrium rate of unemployment. Since the beginning of the financial crisis we observed a disproportional increase in long-term unemployment. Longer unemployment spells make it harder to return to work because of the depreciation of human capital, loss of valuable contacts and general detachment from the labour force. The US is also experiencing increases in long-term unemployment, and we are projecting that it will also experience persistent unemployment above the pre-crisis level (see Holland in this issue).

High youth unemployment also can have long-run consequences. Figure 12 demonstrates that since the beginning of the financial crisis the UK has experienced a 10 percentage point increase in the unemployment rate for 16 to 24 year olds. The level of the youth unemployment rate is somewhat inflated because it includes people in full-time education, who had been looking for a job over the past four weeks. However, the trend towards a substantially higher unemployment rate among young people is unambiguous. In has been shown repeatedly that experience of unemployment in the early years of working life has long-term scarring effects that manifest in lower earnings and a higher probability of experiencing unemployment in the future (Gregg, 2001; Gregg and Tominey, 2005).

caption.p: Youth unemployment rate (aged 16–24)

sec.p: The weakness in demand this year is expected to translate into a 0.3 per cent fall in the level of employment. This adds around 1/2 percentage point to the current unemployment rate, peaking at 8.9 per cent in the fourth quarter of 2012, and a slow decline starting from 2013. Although we do not report forecasts for the youth unemployment rate, we expect it to continue to rise throughout the rest of this year. In our forecast there is a permanent increase in the equilibrium unemployment rate as a consequence of the increase in long-term unemployment experienced in recent years. By 2016 it will gradually decline to 6.4 per cent, which is still almost 1 percentage point above the pre-crisis level (see figure 10).

One puzzling feature of the performance of the UK economy to date has been the evolution of UK productivity. Figure 13 reports output per person hour over the last three recessions, starting with the pre-recession peak. Productivity in the first quarter of this year is still 1 1/2 per cent below the level prior to the onset of recession. In the 1980s and 1990s, productivity was 13 and 15 per cent higher, respectively, at the same point in time. We do not expect any convergence on past productivity perfomance over the next few years. As figure 13 shows, seven years after the onset of recession we expect only a 2 per cent gain in productivity from before the recession. We would not necessarily have expected the level of productivity to match previous economic cycles. The permanent loss of output is reflected in a drop in the level of productivity from where it would otherwise have been, but this probably accounts for less than half the difference in productivity gains. The puzzle over the remaining half remains.

caption.p: UK productivity performance in an historical context

sec.p: Over the course of the recession the rapid adjustment of real product wages enabled firms to hoard labour, in contrast to countries such as the US (Holland et al., 2010). However, this pattern of weak productivity persisted even when the economy returned to a period of growth. A number of hypotheses have been put forward to explain the poor productivity performance. Benito et al. (2010) highlight the effect that tight funding conditions could have on productivity through inhibiting business start-ups as well as constraining the availability of existing firms' working capital, especially those firms perceived as higher risk. Weale (2011) also notes that worker effort per unit of output may have increased relative to the period before the financial crisis. The implied pick-up in demand could well translate into more robust productivity growth. Such outcomes could well be at the expense of additional job creation. A lack of demand must also play a role.7 With the simultaneous deleveraging of the private and public sectors both domestically and in our major export market, the Euro Area, it is difficult to generate sigificant output growth. This also implies a continuation of labour hoarding. But the question remains as to why this should have persisted. Unit labour cost growth remains muted due to the continuation of declines in real product wages. The weakness in the performance of productivity to date poses a risk to our employment forecast. As noted, we expect this weak productivity performance to continue; as product demand rises so will the level of employment. If the labour hoarding is relatively pervasive it might be that the pick-up in demand is not enough to generate additional jobs growth and is instead met through the existing workforce. This poses a risk to our unemployment projections.

sec.title: The public finances
sec.p: Official estimates of fiscal aggregates for the fiscal year 2011–12 show these are broadly in line with the forecasts made by the OBR in March 2012. Public Sector Finance Statistics, which do not exactly match the National Accounts measures presented in table A8, suggest the deficit on the public sector current budget decreased from £98.7 billion in 2010–11 to £97.8 billion in 2011–12. Public sector net borrowing dropped from £136.8 billion to £126 billion over the same period. The outturns also highlight the fact that the change in current receipts, in money terms, is broadly equivalent to the change in current expenditure between the two fiscal years. As the OBR's comment on the public finance release notes, the outturns for both revenues and expenditure were weaker than expected.

The outturns also show that much of the consolidation to date has been through the reduction in capital expenditures. In money terms public sector net investment has dropped from a peak of £43.7 billion in 2009–10 to £29.3 billion in 2011–12 (a reduction of £14.4 billion, or 33 per cent). The peak in the level of net investment in 2009–10 was a major component of the previous government's attempt to inject fiscal stimulus into the economy and thus a fall back in investment spending was inevitable when this stimulus ended. But further reductions in net investment are a crucial component of the government's fiscal consolidation plan. As figure 14 shows, the government, according to the OBR forecast, is planning on reducing net investment as a per cent of GDP to around 1.1 per cent in 2016–17, the lowest level since 2000–01. In comparison, the expenditure plans presented in Budget 2008 were for net investment to reach 2.3 per cent of GDP by 2012–13. We have incorporated these capital expenditure plans into our forecast, although we expect them to be met with a slight lag. This profile has been a feature of our forecast for some time now. In Budget 20108 the government's plan for public sector net investment, as a share of GDP, almost matched the profile presented for the current Budget. The capital expenditure plans are so aggressive that investment spending is expected to continue to fall in money terms, as well as real terms.

caption.p: Public sector net investment

sec.p: Despite the negative headlines, Budget 2012 is expected to have little aggregate effect on the UK macroeconomy. The large number of policy announcements sum to a broadly fiscally neutral stance. But there were some notable and welcome policy announcements. The additional percentage point reduction in the main rate of corporation tax this fiscal year, costing the Exchequer around £0.4 billion this year, and rising to around £0.9 billion in 2016–17, should support business investment once firms become confident about the sources of future demand. The increase in personal allowances beyond what had previously been planned is also welcome. The cost to the Exchequer is estimated to be around £3.5 billion from 2013–14 onwards. This has been funded through a scaling back of the personal allowance available to pensioners, the Bank Levy, various reductions in reliefs and the introduction of anti-avoidance schemes. It is likely that the fiscal multiplier on this is positive but close to zero, given that the boost to incomes through the increase in personal allowance of those of working age is around one fifth of a per cent of GDP. There are longer-run labour supply implications from the increase in the personal allowance and further real increases in the allowance could support the continued drive on benefit reform as well as promoting long-run growth. However, the Budget does not address the current lack of demand.

In April 2012 the government transferred the assets and liabilities from the Royal Mail's pension scheme to the government to be run as an unfunded public sector pension scheme. Treasury calculations suggest a £28 billion value for the assets transferred along with a liability of £38 billion. The transfer is treated in the accounts as a negative effect on net investment and therefore has no effect on the public sector current budget, but it does reduce public sector net borrowing by £28 billion. In the absence of this transfer we would have expected public sector net borrowing to have increased to £135 billion (8.7 per cent of GDP) in 2012–13. But the effect on the public sector's cash requirement is more muted, since only £4.5 billion of the assets are in cash. Of the remaining £23.5 billion in assets, £9 billion are gilts, which the government is able to cancel. The remaining assets of the pension fund will be sold by the government, reducing the financing needs of the UK public sector by around 1 1/2 per cent of GDP. This will have a relatively modest effect on the public sector's financing needs, which the IMF estimates to be close to 15 per cent of GDP this year (IMF, 2012).

The liquid assets, cancellation of gilts and sale of the remaining assets will reduce the level of public sector gross net debt. Future pension payments will be met out of tax revenues, but the contingent liability associated with this is not treated as debt either in the National Accounts or the Public Finance Statistics. They are however, included in the Whole of Government Accounts and as such will be included in the evaluation of the sustainability of the public finances undertaken by the OBR in July 2012. The OBR estimates that these future commitments amount to around £1 1/2 billion per annum. In table A8 we have adjusted our forecast for social benefits to take account of these future additional expenditures.

sec.title: Saving and investment
sec.p: In table A9 we present the data and our forecast for saving and investment, gross of depreciation and as a share of GDP, for the three sectors of the UK domestic economy: households, the corporate sector and general government. The difference between saving and investment for each sector provides an estimate of its consolidated funding position. A positive (negative) figure indicates a sector is a net lender (borrower). The summation of the positions of these three sectors provides an estimate of the aggregate economy's net position with the rest of the world. A current account surplus (deficit) indicates whether the economy needs finance from abroad in order to fund that level of investment in a particular year given the level of national saving undertaken.

As we have noted in past forecasts, the household and corporate sectors are currently net lenders to the rest of the economy. It is the general government sector that remains a net borrower. The net borrowing of government amounted to 7.6 per cent of money GDP in 2011. The household and corporate sectors' net lending equalled around 5.5 per cent of money GDP in that year, with the remainder (1.9 per cent of GDP) required to fund the overall investment position of the UK economy.9 Significantly less funding from abroad was needed by the UK economy in 2011 than previously thought.

We expect the magnitude of household and corporate sector saving to remain elevated, but somewhat below recent peaks (as a percentage of GDP) over the course of the forecast period presented in table A9. Household saving is expected to peak this year at 5.7 per cent of GDP, before easing back to just over 5 per cent by 2016. Household saving is expected to continue to increase over the next five years; however, gross disposable income growth is expected to lag behind the rate of growth of nominal GDP. The corporate sector saving rate is expected to remain at 11 1/4 per cent of GDP, or higher over the course of the forecast period, but below the recent peak reached in 2008 (15.1 per cent) as the financial crisis intensified and the UK economy dropped into recession. As credit conditions and uncertainties ease, the desire to retain cash is expected to lessen somewhat and this is likely to be reflected in the saving behaviour of the corporate sector.10

The general government sector is expected to remain a net borrower over the next five years. However, net borrowing is expected to shrink from 7.6 per cent of GDP in 2011 to 2.1 per cent in 2016. The government's fiscal consolidation programme shrinks the general government's borrowing requirement through a combination of a reduction in dis-saving (predominately via real-term reductions in current expenditure) and a reduction in general government investment. Government investment is expected to fall from 2.1 per cent of GDP in 2011 to 1.2 per cent in 2016.

A balanced economy is at the core of the economic model the government would like the UK to have in future years. The exact definition of a balanced economy is not always entirely clear. We take the view that a more balanced economy is one that is less dependent on consumption than in the past and where the level of national saving is high enough to fund the desired level of investment. Thus improving the balance of payments should be a key indicator. We expect the current account deficit to narrow from 1.9 per cent of GDP in 2011 to around balance in 2016. Closing the economy's funding gap is a pre-requisite for moving towards the funding of future spending commitments associated with an ageing population allowing the accumulation of net assets. We expect a significant improvement in the current account this year and next (1.7 and 0.9 per cent of GDP, respectively). This is, in large part, a consequence of a relatively weak domestic economy and corresponding weakness in demand for imports rather than a robust contribution from the export sector.

sec.title: The medium term
sec.p: In ‘normal times’ our projection for the medium term would be one of the economy ‘on-trend’. That is to say it would be one of an economy operating at capacity.

Given the disequilibrium the UK finds itself in, and much of the global economy, the medium-term projection is our view of the economy's adjustment back to an equilibrium. The future path of the UK economy will be shaped by further shocks of varying magnitudes. These are by definition unpredictable, and do not affect the published medium-term projection.

There are factors which will shape the future path of the economy which are inherently more predictable. These include announced government policy with regards to the shape and scale of public expenditures, tax policy and policy induced changes to the labour force through such things as tax and benefit reform, migration policy and general pension policy.

The government announced an additional 1 percentage point reduction in the main corporation tax rate from the second quarter of 2012. This should boost potential output in the UK through increasing the equilibrium capital stock via a reduction in the user cost of capital. Simulations using our global econometric model, NiGEM, suggest that this change in tax policy will increase the UK's capital stock by 0.3 per cent and potential output by around 0.1 per cent. While 1 percentage point reduction in the main corporation tax rate is modest, the government has announced a cumulative 6 percentage point reduction in the corporation tax rate between the second quarter of 2011 and the second quarter of 2014, which should have a significant positive effect on potential output in the UK. The expansion of the labour force through the equalisation of men and women's State Pension ages should also raise the productive potential of the economy. The government's aim of reducing net migration to ‘tens of thousands’ would reduce the potential output of the UK economy through a reduction in labour supply. The effect on the economy could well be larger than macro models suggest if this leads to bottlenecks forming in the UK economy.

The rate of growth in potential, or trend, GDP growth is around 2 per cent per annum. Table A10 reports a rate of growth significantly above this. Such rates of growth are necessary if the substantial negative output gap in the UK is to close over the medium term. While the output gap will eventually close, the unemployment rate is not expected to return to its level prior to the onset of the financial crisis. The unemployment rate drops from an average of 8.6 per cent this year and next to over 6 per cent in the medium term. Recent work by the OECD suggests that the equilibrium unemployment rate has increased in many countries, including the UK (Guichard and Rusticelli, 2011).

On current plans fiscal policy in the UK will remain tight until at least 2016–17. In stark contrast, monetary policy is expected to remain loose well into the medium term. Bank Rate is expected to average only 2 1/2 per cent per annum over the period 2017–21. But such a loose stance in monetary policy does not lead to above target inflation rates. The persistent presence of a negative output gap and the assumption that monetary policy remains credible are central to such outcomes. Deviations from either of these could well lead to a period of above target inflation. Such a loss of credibility would be troubling, given that interest rates would need to be raised far more aggressively to combat a given increase in the rate of inflation. While concerns about such risks are warranted, this should not dissuade the use of monetary policy to stimulate demand as long as a significant negative output gap and elevated unemployment both persist.
